preface.title: Introduction
preface.para: Augusta is an open source Ada compiler developed as a personal project by me, Peter C. Chapin. As a person interested in Ada related technologies, I created Augusta primarily for my own education and enjoyment. However, it is also my hope that Augusta will eventually provide another option besides GNAT for those interested in using an open source Ada compiler. Although GNAT is a fine product, I believe in the value of diversity when it comes to available programming tools.

Augusta is a long term project. Since I can only work on it in my spare time and since I'm not expecting many contributors at first, I anticipate it taking years before Augusta reaches any level of maturity. Yet to put a concrete time line on my work I have decided to release version 1.0 of Augusta on December 31, 2025. At that time I intend to have a usable compiler ready, for some reasonable definition of "usable."

Augusta is written primarily in the Scala programming language. I chose Scala because it is a functional language, and thus supports features that I believe will be helpful for compiler construction (such as algebraic data types and pattern matching). Accordingly I intend to write Augusta in as purely a functional style as feasible with the hope that doing so will make the code more understandable, more reliable, and more amenable to parallelization. In addition, Scala gives me access to an enormous collection of Java libraries, tools, and technologies, many of which are very powerful and highly mature. I intend to capitalize on that legacy as much as possible during the development of Augusta.

I understand that Scala is an unusual choice as an implementation language for an Ada compiler. I understand that I would be more likely to attract help from the Ada community if I wrote Augusta in Ada. However, as a personal project I have the luxury of selecting tools that interest me even if they might not be strategically optimal. I hope my choice of Scala pays off in the long run. If the compiler is easier to write or if Augusta eventually becomes a bridge between the Scala/Java and Ada communities, my choice might prove to be strategic after all.

August targets the LLVM compiler framework. This allows me to defer the details of low level code generation and optimization to the framework. Thus in theory Augusta supports all target architectures supported by LLVM, both now and in the future. This approach also allows me to capitalize on future advances made in LLVM technology. However, unlike high level virtual machines such as the JVM or the CLR, LLVM should not restrict my implementation options. I believe it will be easier to accurately implement a language like Ada, which is intended to support low level programming, on top of a low level framework.

I anticipate that as Augusta matures others will become attracted to the project and may join the effort. For this reason, aside from this introduction, the documentation is written as if it is being authored by a group of contributors rather than just a single person. This will reduce the amount of editing needed when there actually is a group of Augusta contributors.

Although I hope others will become interested in this project in the future, I am also realistic enough to know that I will most likely be the only contributor for some time. People don't want to spend time on a grand project that just fizzles out in a couple of months. I will need to prove Augusta's seriousness by demonstrating a sustained effort and steady progress before anyone is likely to be willing to invest in it. This actually suits me fine because it allows me to shape the design and structure of the project on my own before others with competing views start to participate.
This documentation describes both the design and use of the Augusta compiler.
